DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Says Reporters Shouldn't Have To Testify
DOC.TEXT: Journalists' confidential sources and information they gathered must be ``highly material and relevant,'' and unavailable from elsewhere, before reporters can be compelled to reveal them, the state Supreme Court has ruled. The 5-0 ruling released Wednesday, overturned contempt citations against two West Virginia reporters. In September, Circuit Judge Patrick G. Henry III held in contempt reporters Ron Hudok of The Evening Journal of Martinsburg and Natasha Singh of WXVA-FM in Charles Town. They had refused to testify at a hearing about Circuit Judge Thomas Steptoe Jr.'s decision to fire an employee. ``In this case, the information sought to be obtained was tenuous at best to the main purpose of the hearing, which was to provide (the employee) a hearing on her discharge,'' the Supreme Court said. Eight news media groups, including The Associated Press and the West Virginia Broadcasters Association, had filed a legal brief in support of the newspaper and radio station. ``The decision ... is really a victory for the people of West Virginia because it allows reporters for all media to write the comments and viewpoints of the people who live in this state,'' said Page Burdette, editor of The Evening Journal. Burdette said he hopes the issue will prompt lawmakers to pass West Virginia's first ``shield'' laws for reporters. Such legislation would help journalists protect news sources to whom they've promised anonymity in return for information. Singh said she was relieved. ``I'm just glad I get to eat turkey at Christmas and I don't have to be in jail,'' she said. The opinion, written by Justice Thomas Miller, said there could be cases when reporters' information is pertinent to a legal proceeding. In the case of Hudok and Singh, however, First Amendment privilege should prevail, the opinion said. The case stemmed from Steptoe's decision to fire Magistrate Clerk Linda Butner in June. The judge said she publicly injected herself into a criminal matter pending before magistrate court by talking to reporters. Steptoe had sought to force the reporters to testify about their conversations with Butner, who Henry said is bound by judicial ethics to refrain from commenting on court matters.
